aspects of graph homomorphisms, the central problem is one of existence â€“
does an input graph GğºG admit a homomorphism to a fixed target graph Hğ»H?
(The graphs considered here are undirected graphs with possible loops but no
parallel edges.)
This is known as the graph homomorphism problem. It was shown inÂ 
that this problem is polynomial-time solvable when Hğ»H has a loop or is
bipartite, and is NP-complete otherwise. This is known as the dichotomy
of graph homomorphisms (seeÂ ). The core of a
graph Hğ»H is a subgraph of Hğ»H with the smallest number of vertices to which
Hğ»H admits a homomorphism; note that such a subgraph is unique up to
isomorphism. A graph with a loop has a vertex with a loop as its core, and
a (non-empty) bipartite graph has an edge as its core. Thus an equivalent way

solvable when the core of Hğ»H has at most one edge, and is NP-complete

the context of constraint satisfaction problems. The Feder-Vardi dichotomy

This exciting development focused research attention on additional homomorphism

The computational aspects of existence of homomorphisms
in signed graphs â€” given a fixed signed graph (H,Ï€)ğ»ğœ‹(H,\pi), does an input signed
